description: From Middle English disparage (noun), disparagen (verb), from Old French desparage (noun), desparagier (verb), from des- (“dis-”) + parage (“equal rank, rank”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Inequality in marriage; marriage with an inferior.

verbs.description: disparage (third-person singular simple present disparages, present participle disparaging, simple past and past participle disparaged)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To match unequally; to degrade or dishonor.
To dishonor by a comparison with what is inferior; to lower in rank or estimation by actions or words; to speak slightingly of; to depreciate; to undervalue.
examples: those forbidding appearances which sometimes disparage the actions of men sincerely pious
Had he disparaged my personal appearance I should in all probability have laughed at him with lively indifference
